entry.title: Baltimore Police Keep Cellphone Surveillance Under Wraps
entry.summary: This is not the first case to inspire a push-pull between prosecutors, defense attorneys and judges about revealing details of the Baltimore Police Department's use of the clandestine technology.

entry.title: Baltimore police often surveil cellphones amid US secrecy
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE (AP) - The Baltimore Police Department has an agreement with the U.S. government to withhold certain information about secretive cellphone surveillance technology from the public and even the courts, according to a confidential agreement obtained by The Associated Press.

The Baltimore police entered into an agreement with the Justice Department in 2011, which calls for the department to withhold information about the device in "press releases, court documents, during judicial hearings or during other public forums and proceedings."

In practice, Baltimore police officers are interpreting the non-disclosure agreement as instructing them to withhold evidence from the court, and ignore subpoenas relating to the technology.

Cabreja said under questioning from defense attorneys that he did not comply with a subpoena to bring the device to court because of a nondisclosure agreement between the Baltimore police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

entry.title: Feds: Baltimore jail illegally keeping juveniles in solitary
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE (AP) - The U.S. Justice Department says teenagers awaiting trial on adult charges in Baltimore are being kept in solitary confinement for far too long - up to 143 days in one case.

The State of Maryland says juvenile detainees accused of breaking jail rules should spend no longer than a week in solitary, and yet teenagers inside the Baltimore City Detention Center are being isolated for 13 days on average, and in some cases, far longer.

entry.title: Will Martin O'Malley run for president? Find out on May 30
entry.summary:
O'Malley plans to announce his presidential intentions on May 30 in Baltimore, a move that could present another Democratic challenger to Hillary Rodham Clinton.

The ex-Baltimore mayor, who has visited early-voting states, has tried to present himself as a champion of progressive causes and a fresh face for liberals hesitant to support Clinton.

O'Malley, mayor from 1999 until he was elected governor in 2006, has defended his work to curb violent crime in Baltimore and signaled it would play a leading role in a presidential campaign.

entry.title: In aftermath of Gray's death, Baltimore's economy needs more residents with money to spend
entry.summary:
Baltimore is actively seeking to bring these people back, since their spending power could help restore neighborhoods, expand the economic base and energize what has been a tentative comeback for the 620,000-person city.

Compared with rival cities that have enjoyed a renaissance, Baltimore's upper-middle class remains a relatively small slice of the city.

Nearly 43 percent of families in Washington proper earn at least $100,000, for example, compared with just 16 percent in Baltimore.

entry.title: RX for Baltimore economy: More residents with money to spend
entry.summary:
The Census Bureau shows that Baltimore has added 3,700 families with incomes above $100,000 since 2010, gains that have helped pull many neighborhoods out of a decades-long slide.

Just two weeks after the protests and violence following Gray's death, nearly 270 potential homebuyers registered to spend their Saturday morning at a high school in West Baltimore to tour the neighborhood.

entry.summary: Pointing to a wave of violence in Baltimore, Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that the nation's criminal justice system has gotten "out of balance" and must be restored through steps such as the use of body cameras by every police department in the country.

entry.title: Baltimore clashes: violence flares after Freddie Gray's funeral
entry.summary:
Seven Baltimore police officers were injured on Monday as rioters threw bricks and stones and burned patrol cars in violent protests after the funeral of a black man who died in police custody.

The riots broke out just a few blocks from the site of the funeral of 25-year-old Freddie Gray in northwest Baltimore and then spread through other parts of the city, after local law enforcement warned of a threat by gangs.

Baltimore Police Captain Eric Kowalczyk said at a police briefing that one of the injured police officers was unresponsive and several had broken bones.

entry.title: US diplomat recalls racial tension in Baltimore
entry.summary:
A U.S. diplomat opened her speech on Iranian nuclear negotiations talking about how she grew up going to civil rights marches and says her father once helped baseball star Frank Robinson find a home in an all-white neighborhood of Baltimore.

The recent case of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police, has intensified a national debate over police treatment of African-Americans.

entry.title: Barack Obama to send aide to Freddie Gray funeral in Baltimore on Monday

entry.title: Former Baltimore Raven Ray Lewis sues attorney over failed MVP Lanes development project
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - Former Baltimore Ravens star Ray Lewis is suing his former attorney over a failed development project he says cost him $1.5 million.

The suit accuses the Baltimore lawyer of convincing Lewis to sign a $1.5 million line of credit for the project, and later asking for another $200,000.

entry.title: Amazon.com introduces one-hour delivery to Baltimore, Miami
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - Amazon.com is expanding its one-hour delivery Prime Now service to Baltimore and Miami.

The company says that the service will be expanded only to certain zip codes within Baltimore and Miami at first, but it plans to further expand within each city soon.

The last seven years that my family and I have spent in Baltimore have by far been the best of our lives.

Thank you, Baltimore Ravens, for all you have done for my family and I.

I love you all very much, and I'll always be proud to say I played for the Baltimore Ravens.
